TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, is attending a health and community services ministerial council meeting in Sydney and will be absent from question time today. During Senator Crowley's absence, Senator Cook will take questions relating to human services and health, including family services, Senator Schacht will take questions on social security and I will take questions relating to the status of women.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to expectations expressed today by respected economists that, as a result of the government's lax fiscal policy, interest rates are expected to rise by at least one per cent in the near future. Does the minister appreciate that this will add $864 a year to the average home loan? When will the government come clean and acknowledge that a failure of its policies will result in interest rate rises and that new home buyers and small businesses should be factoring this into domestic budgets and business plans?

—On the substantive matters in issue, I have nothing to add to what I said yesterday which, in essence, was that at some stage of the recovery interest rates will need to rise to ensure that inflation remains low. Official interest rates have fallen to their lowest level since the 1970s and we have to expect that there will be an increase in rates at some stage of the recovery. But interest rates will not rise in the near term because inflation in Australia is at historically low levels and is among the lowest in the Western world. That is the truth of the matter. Those are the fundamentals of the Australian economy, and there is no rational basis for any interest rates rise in the near term given that particular inflationary environment.

PARA.TAB: On the subject of fiscal responsibility generally, we do not need to be lectured by the likes of Senator Hill and the opposition on this particular matter. Our responsibility has been to identify a path of fiscal management by this country which will return to budget in approximate balance within a few short years, 1996-97. That has been universally acknowledged to be a totally responsible approach to be adopted by the government and it is one that is, in fact, perfectly capable of achievement in a way that will produce a sustained low inflation but, at the same time, high growth environment.

The contrast is quite spectacular between the responsible approach that has been adopted by the government and the conspicuously, vulgarly, populist, opportunistic approach that has been adopted by members of the opposition on this as on every other matter. They sing with different tunes and different songs. Mr Costello says he wants a balanced budget; Mr Downer, of course, wants to spend money on everything under the sun that will appeal to this or that interest group as he systematically works his way around hawking his body to this or that interest group in an attempt to get away from the desiccated imagery of his predecessor.

He has not persuaded anybody so far; he will not in the future because there is no substance or integrity in the opposition's policy. Those opposite might have changed their leadership, they might have changed their front bench, but there is an iron law of arithmetic that applies in this sort of situation; that is, nothing plus or minus nothing still equals nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not the real case, as Mr Mark Hopkinson, the head of financial markets in Schroeders, said this morning, that the political stakes are pretty high in this exercise? Is it not the real fact that the government is concentrating on the internal political consequences rather than giving Australian business and home buyers a real appreciation of what is to logically follow from its fiscal failures? Does the minister not recognise that yesterday bond yields soared to their highest levels since April 1992 and short-term interest rates rose sharply? Does this not logically mean that in the relatively near future there will be a substantial lift in interest rates, speculated today to be at least one per cent? The government should be advising home buyers and small business to be taking this into account.

—I made perfectly clear that, the way this system operates, we cannot work on the assumption that movements of this kind can be resisted in perpetuity. It is the case that at some stage of the recovery cycle we do have to anticipate some rise in interest rates. But there is no ground for anticipating such a rise in the near term when the fundamentals remain as solid as they are. If the opposition had any responsibility at all in this respect, it would be trying to get some sanity and balance back into the bond market, not talking up the irrationality that is conspicuously there at the moment.

PARA.TAB: There are no fundamental reasons in the Australian market. There is a bit of volatility that is generated by the situation in the United States and overseas. But, if we look at the fundamentals of the Australian market—the underlying inflation rate and the reasonable expectations this economy has for the future—there is simply no foundation for the behaviour of the markets in this respect at the moment. For the opposition to talk up the degree of irrationality that is prevailing at the moment is to perform no service at all to home owners, home buyers or anyone else.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Defence, relates to aircraft noise in Darwin and follows a question asked by Senator Jones on 4 May. In answer to Senator Jones's question, the minister indicated that he had asked the Deputy Chief of Air Staff, Air Vice Marshal Les Fisher, to visit Darwin to investigate the issue of military aircraft noise in that city. Has Air Vice Marshal Fisher now reported and, if so, could the minister advise the Senate of the results of the investigation which he foreshadowed last month? Will the minister make the report of the Deputy Chief of Air Staff available to the Senate?

—As I foreshadowed in the Senate last month, the Deputy Chief of Air Staff, Air Vice Marshal Fisher, visited Darwin from 10 to 13 May to undertake a full investigation into aircraft noise in Darwin. His brief included allegations that visiting pilots were straying from their designated flight paths and agreed procedures. As part of that investigation, a wide range of Darwin people were interviewed, including community leaders, business leaders, residents and other interest groups. I will summarise the major findings of the investigation.

PARA.TAB: There was no evidence that the United States marine corps pilots strayed from flight plans. There was evidence of one marine corps pilot not complying with an air traffic direction. The pilot misunderstood the requirements and was counselled by the marine corps authorities to prevent a recurrence. There was evidence that noise abatement procedures were breached. However, the noise abatement procedures promulgated by the Royal Australian Air Force lacked clarity and could be misunderstood, especially by foreigners. In addition, they were not fully effective in reducing military jet noise to reasonable levels. No arrangements were in place to ensure that all pilots had received and understood the procedures. Lastly, the public relations effort for exercises by foreign services operating from Darwin has not been effective.

I have now had an opportunity to consider Air Vice Marshal Fisher's report and its conclusions. I have agreed to a number of sensible changes to existing procedures which will minimise aircraft noise. Revised noise abatement procedures will be put in place which more closely reflect the suburban disposition of Darwin and the concern of residents. They will require military fast jet aircraft to conduct straight-in approaches by day and night, except during major defence exercises such as Pitch Black and Kangaroo. Arrangements will be put into place to ensure that all pilots comply with the revised noise abatement arrangements.

Additional resources will be provided to control and monitor foreign force activities. A much greater effort will be made to ensure that the Darwin community is kept fully informed of why, when and for how long foreign military aircraft will be operating from Darwin and of the efforts being made to minimise noise. With regard to the last part of the honourable senator's question, I can advise the Senate that Air Vice Marshal Fisher's report will be tabled in the Senate tomorrow.

—This is an extraordinary intervention. Here is an exhibition which showcases the best in Australian science, which was viewed by the Vice-President of Indonesia, and which is regarded by the Indonesian media and expert commentators as a key exhibition and one of the best of its kind, and the opposition complains about it. PARA.TAB: President Suharto and the Minister of State for Research and Technology, Dr Habibie, both visited the exhibition in May this year, which was then premiered as part of Ristek, the Indonesian science and technology exhibition. This exhibition represents areas in science where Australia is a world leader and, importantly, areas in science that have a direct, useful and practical application to the needs of Indonesia and, on a broader scale, the needs of this region. TALK.START.PARA: —Nano-technology?

—As Senator Campbell interjected, nano-technology is included, as is aerospace technology, medicine, biotechnology, engineering and education. The exhibition forms part of the major trade and cultural promotion, Australia 94, that Australia is undertaking in Indonesia over the next few weeks.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, the `Visions for the Future' exhibition showcases some of the best examples of Australian science and technology and is compelling because of the interactive nature of the displays. Interactive touch-screen guides introduce people to Australia's remarkable achievements in science and technology in both English and Bahasa Indonesian. They refer people to the companies and institutions that manufacture the particular exhibits. It will be particularly important in showing Indonesians from a wide range of backgrounds that there are significant numbers of areas in which Australian expertise can assist Indonesia's economic development.

I am very pleased that the exhibition had already led to the signing of $12 million in joint ventures between one of the Australian participants and a new Indonesia based company that will carry out environmental and research monitoring. There are many other examples of areas of potential cooperation between our two countries. For example, Australian scientists have developed the world's most efficient solar cells and solar powered streetlights. As well, Australian researchers were the first in the world to build the bucky-balls, large soccer ball shaped molecules of carbon, which will have enormous use in industry, the environment and health care. Australian scientists have synthesised a new drug that may cure and prevent all forms of influenza virus. The world's aircraft manufacturers are turning to the Australian development—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Has the minister noted the comments of his ministerial colleague Gary Johns that for too long the Labor government has been responding to the demands of minority groups, which he defined to include `women, migrants, blacks and homosexuals', rather than the real and genuine needs of mainstream Australia? Was Mr Johns outlining a new government strategy to refashion itself so as to crudely attempt to appeal to those many Australians who have been ignored by the policies of this government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that Mr Johns has been rather misunderstood on the point he was making. As I am advised, he was emphasising the virtues of tolerance in Australian society and recognising the need for people to live together. In a subsequent communication to the centenary advisory committee, he said:

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In light of the current crisis on the Korean peninsula and in light of Australia's role both as a supplier of uranium to the region and as chair of the International Atomic Energy Agency board of governors, will the minister inform the Senate how the decision by Australia to support any UN sanctions was reached? Was the issue debated by either the Labor parliamentary caucus or cabinet? If the matter was not debated at either level, who made the decision to support UN sanctions and on what basis? Will the minister release details of the role played by the Australian chair of the IAEA's board of governors in the North Korean stand-off? Did Australia's position on the IAEA require the Australian government to agree to UN sanctions against North Korea even at the risk of war on the peninsula? Would the minister explain why Australia, as a nation concerned with the preservation of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, supports US efforts to impose UN sanctions on North Korea? (Time expired)

—The question of UN sanctions in relation to North Korea remains hypothetical at this stage. Hopefully, in the light of the recent developments that I talked about yesterday, it will not be necessary to go down that particular path. But, if UN sanctions ever are applied in this situation, Australia has an obligation as a UN member to support those sanctions. It would be quite unthinkable for us to do otherwise. In the event that mandatory measures are adopted by the Security Council, Australia, like every other member of the UN, would be bound to implement them.

PARA.TAB: Support for the UN in these respects has been a longstanding pillar of Australian foreign policy and there is absolutely no need in that context to have any formalised approval procedures as new situations evolve. If they are consistent with established principle and established approaches—as this is, as I have just described—there is no issue that needs to be considered case by case.

So far as our role in relation to the International Atomic Energy Agency is concerned, we played the very responsible role that one would expect us to be playing as a longstanding member in good standing of that particular organisation and as chairman of it during the recent troubled period. We are a country with a very strong commitment to the IAEA and to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. We do take the view that it is appalling for any country to walk away from its obligations under that particular treaty and we will always, as a result, be among those willing to apply appropriate measures in situations where countries do not discharge their obligations formally and solemnly entered into. That, regrettably, was the situation so far as North Korea was concerned.

Senator Margetts was impliedly asking me about the situation in relation to Japan and other countries that might be closer perhaps to possessing nuclear weapons. I just say, in anticipation of that, that in the case of Japan it is a country with very good standing as a member of the non-proliferation treaty and the Atomic Energy Agency. It is not a matter of Australia ignoring anything in relation to Japan's nuclear conduct in this respect. We have absolutely no doubt whatsoever that the only nuclear activity in which Japan has been engaged, or is likely to be engaged, is in relation to peaceful purposes.

In the case of other countries that may have nuclear weapons possession potential—Israel, India, Pakistan are those that are most commonly mentioned in this respect—the situation is that, regrettably, they are quite outside the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. They are not parties to any of these international obligations and, as such, there is no basis on which the international community can effectively respond to any new development. That is a situation we would very much like to change and have been working actively diplomatically for a very long time to try to change, not least in the context of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty review conference which comes up next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Does this mean that Australia will be jumping on the bandwagon with any particular country that the United States of America thinks is a good mark in relation to nuclear non-proliferation?

—That is not quite the way in which I would put it. When a country is in flagrant and deliberate violation of its solemnly entered into treaty obligations under something as important as the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, it is very difficult for the United States, Australia or anyone else in the international community to simply stand back and say that that kind of behaviour should go unresponded to. At the same time, of course, in a very delicate situation of this kind where we are trying to take into account not only the effect of past actions but possible future actions, it does make sense to try, so far as humanly possible, not to make the situation any worse and to go down the path of a rational and negotiated solution. That, as I said yesterday and elsewhere, is the way we believe this situation should evolve if it possibly can.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it correct that, as reported in the newspapers this morning, Mr Keating has ruled out a referendum prior to any change in the flag? Is it correct, therefore, that the government proposes to make a change in the flag without seeking the formal approval of the Australian people? Further, if the government is not prepared to support a referendum, what approach does the government have in mind to test public opinion on this issue?

—The flag has never been enshrined in the constitution, not surprisingly, given that there have been so many different ones during the course of our national history, as those opposite have never been prepared to acknowledge. It has always been a matter of statutory provision, no more than that, and as such, not being in the constitution, it would not be appropriate to apply to any decision about the flag the kinds of procedures that are appropriate for constitutional change, that is, a formal referendum with all the complicated requirements and enormous expense associated with that.

PARA.TAB: However, the government has made clear on many occasions that, firstly, details of how any new flag might be chosen have not even been considered by the government. It is not on the agenda at the moment. Secondly, we have made clear—and nothing that Mr Keating has said has changed this—that no scheme for a change would be contemplated which did not involve some act of choice by the Australian electorate between the current design and any proposed new design or alternative designs that might be put. What kind of act of choice might be most appropriately involved in the situation is one for determination closer to the time. The government has made it perfectly clear that we do not see this as being a matter for unilateral government action. It is a matter on which the community should have a say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I have a supplementary question. As Senator Gareth Evans knows, we have had a problem in recent weeks of the government rewriting history. We have had one national flag since 1903, so he was wrong on that. It was a national flag that the Labor Party was prepared to fly and be proud of.
—What is the question?

—Thank you, Senator. Could the honourable senator keep quiet for a moment? In 1992 it was said that a cabinet paper was being prepared on this whole issue, on how the government proposes to make a change to the Australian flag. What happened to that cabinet submission? What forced the government to change its mind? Surely the Australian people are entitled to know what the government has in mind when it talks about an act of choice.

—I am not aware of anything having happened to take further any preliminary discussion that might have been involved in 1992. But let me tell the Senate what happened in 1967. That was the year when Mr Harold Holt, as leader of the then government, on behalf of the government dumped the Royal Australian Navy's white ensign with its red cross of St George, under which thousands of Australians had served and died in three wars in the naval capacity, in favour of the RAN's present ensign with the Southern Cross in blue. There was not any active public discussion or public choice. There was no referendum, no publicity, no nothing; it was just a unilateral stroke of the pen. It was a flag under which Australians in their thousands had fought and died in three wars.

PARA.TAB: That is the kind of regard the other side has for this particular issue. That is the kind of selective indignation, that is the kind of selective history, we have whenever this particular issue is raised. Let us have no more nonsense. Let us have a little bit of informed, rational and sensible debate.

PARA.TAB: The Small Business Forum, established by this government, is a great success. My department's submission, along with many others from concerned individuals, is being assessed and considered by Queensland authorities. Queensland government officials came to Canberra on 14 June to discuss the Commonwealth's concern. I understand that Queensland authorities are doing more work to assess the impact of the project on the area's world heritage values and that an environmental management and monitoring plan for the project is being negotiated with the developer.

PARA.TAB: My department's main concerns relate to the potential impact of the dredging on the marine fauna and flora in the Hinchinbrook Channel and of increased tourist activities in the sensitive reef and rainforest communities of the region. It is premature for the government to consider any use of Commonwealth powers to protect world heritage values. That provided that no works would be undertaken in designated areas specified in the national capital plan without the written approval of the authority.

PARA.TAB: I am informed by the NCPA that legal advice provided is that the telecommunications exemption activities regulations, subsection 116(1), exempt the telecommunications carriers from the application of state and territory planning laws. The regulations do not refer to Commonwealth law and, as such, the carriers are not exempt from the provisions in the national capital plan. That is the short end of the legal advice.

Under the terms of the national capital plan, any proposed major expansion of hilltop use will be subject to the development of a comprehensive telecommunications plan. Such a plan does not yet exist. I am further informed that talks are being held between the NCPA, the ACT planning minister, Bill Wood, the ACT Planning Authority and senior representatives of Telecom, Optus and Vodafone, being the three mobile phone carriers involved. I am further informed that all parties have accepted the legal position.

As a starting point to the development of the telecommunications master plan for the ACT, the carriers are providing the NCPA with details of all present and proposed future installations. The study suggests that health export revenues have the potential to increase by an average of 25 per cent over the next five years from roughly $30 million last year. The special trade representative John Button, who is well known to Senator Cooney, led a health mission to Japan as recently as November of last year. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the document National action plan: Australia. As my colleague Senator Tambling said, it was tabled in Geneva in February. I note that the same estimates committee is meeting this afternoon. That is the reason why the department has decided to table this report today without, I might say, any proper reason for debate.

PARA.TAB: There are two things that I want to draw particular attention to. The first is that the handling of this report shows the attitude of this government to the parliament versus the United Nations. Priority is given to rushing what is a major, important report—in some ways a report which will cause concern in the Australian community—to Geneva, not to consulting with the Australian people or the parliament.

Secondly, this document demonstrates in so many ways that Senator Evans and his colleagues are obsessed with these UN conventions and that they desire to incorporate the UN system more and more into our legal system. Senator Evans is very proud of the fact that ours was the first country to table a national action plan as requested. Senator Evans wants this document to be a model for all other countries. This self-promotion of Senator Evans at the UN is becoming a habit. We certainly hope that it has nothing to do with his career plans for when he leaves this parliament.

I want to draw the parliament's attention to specific issues on pages 6 and 7 of this document, which deal with the attitude of this government to opening up appeals and complaints to UN committees, thereby incorporating UN committees into our legal system. Yesterday in the Senate I tabled the names of the people on the three committees that the Hawke and Keating governments have decided should play a role in our domestic disputes. As noted yesterday, many of the members of those committees are nominated by governments which simply do not practise human rights as we understand them.

When talking about the sovereignty of a nation and about being proud to be Australian, one of the things we would not do is overturn the philosophy of the Australia Act and involve United Nations committees in Australian domestic law and constitutional law. We would not do it because we believe in the philosophy of the Australia Act; it is appropriate for domestic issues to be treated in our domestic courts and in our parliaments and for laws to be ruled on by known judges.

There was no need to take the decision to involve the United Nations in our domestic activities. As distinct from Senator Evans, Senator Schacht has been quite honest about the effect of this. Senator Schacht was the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade when it produced a report that looked at the issue of human rights around the world. That report recognised the fact that UN conventions and treaties have the capacity to limit the sovereignty of nations. Senator Schacht was quite clear about that, and I have no particular argument with him.

However, the republican Mr Keating and the republican Senator Evans have raised the issue of the independence and sovereignty of our country. The natural question is: why on earth has a decision been taken to involve these UN committees in our domestic activities? This parliament was never asked whether they should be involved; no law was ever passed in this parliament to permit it.The trouble is that an increasing number of cases will now go offshore to be ruled on by these committees in Geneva. That is a big problem for Australia and a problem that will grow in the years to come because these committees will make rulings that do not have the support of any significant section of the Australian community except for the group that feels it has a particular problem. TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate long, but this matter will be submerged if I do not raise it now. It relates to funds being sought from the Advance to the Minister for Finance for an ex-gratia payment to Mr Josef Tokic, as approved by the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) in April 1994.

PARA.TAB: The Senate would be aware that Mr Tokic received a bullet wound to the neck while taking part in a demonstration outside the Yugoslav Consulate-General in Woollahra, Sydney, in November 1988. Mr Tokic sued the government of Yugoslavia for damages for negligence in respect of the incident. In December 1991 the court awarded him $46,854, including costs. The application for funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance stated:

SPEECH.PARA: An ex-gratia payment was sought on the grounds that it was not possible to execute the judgment against the Government of Yugoslavia. The defendant government (Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia) no longer exists and is unlikely to be replaced by a government which would assume the judgment debt. Due to the current political circumstances in the former Yugoslavia, the Australian government cannot exert the level of diplomatic influence it would in normal situations. Because of consular immunity, it is not possible to take action against the Consul-General of the Government of Yugoslavia in Sydney, or other assets of the Government held in Australia.

The Minister for Finance approved an Act of Grace payment, due to the unique circumstances which exist to prevent Mr Tokic enforcing the judgment. The Act of Grace payment is made on the condition that the judgment debt is assigned to the Commonwealth.

There is no doubt that all honourable senators would support the fact that Mr Tokic is to receive his money. It is a disgrace that it has taken so long for him to get his money—from December 1991. The problem is why on earth this government is not proceeding against the property held by the former government of Yugoslavia in Australia. It seems to me totally inadequate to say that consular immunity prevents the government from doing so.

PARA.TAB: I draw to the government's attention the fact that in the United States the various cities are now proceeding against the consular and diplomatic officials for multimillions of dollars in relation to back parking fines that have resulted from the arrogant way in which diplomatic and consular representatives have ignored the rules in relation to parking in those municipalities and cities.

I am under the impression that if the government had such a mind it could well proceed against assets held here by the former government of Yugoslavia. I regret, firstly, the massive delay in making the payment to Mr Tokic and, secondly, the fact that the government has shown no enthusiasm in pursuing this matter. As a result the taxpayers of Australia have to foot the bill—of course, Mr Tokic is totally entitled to get the money—when the government of Australia should be

SPEECH.PARA: exercising, what I understand to be, its rights to get restitution from the former government of Yugoslavia.

PARA.TAB: One of the factors involved is that it has taken so long for the government to do anything about it. That may have increased the problems involved. If the government has taken a different view from the view taken by the United States authorities, I think it owes it to the Senate and to the people of Australia to explain why. The Americans can pursue diplomats for these judgment debts, as I understand it in these matters, whereas the Australian government apparently finds itself incapable of doing so.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 12 May 1994:

(a) & (b) I wrote to Mr Scott, who presented Mr Irwin's allegations, outlining that because Mr Irwin was not employed under a federal award, the Commonwealth Department of Industrial Relations does not have the jurisdiction to pursue any payments which may be owed to him by his former employers, Cenrim Pty Ltd and Jaytron Pty Ltd.
